fields.summary: Limit of 2 access keys and signing certs per user should be enforced

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
In 4.1 we added limits for IAM credentials (EUCA-9940) and also restricted generation of certificates for the credential download (EUCA-10005)

We should allow the download limit to be disabled and disable it for upgraded systems so the behavior does not change on upgrade.
fields.summary: Disable certificate download limit on upgraded systems

comments.body:
We could add an option for credential download such as:

  authentication.credential_download_certificate = ( Never | Absent | Limited )

where:

* Never - never generate a certificate for the download
* Absent - generate a certificate if the user has none
* Limited - generate a certificate if within IAM limit

The IAM limit is separately configurable and would be set to a very high value on upgraded systems so it was effectively disabled.

I was planning on setting the default as "Limited" as part of this fix so the IAM limit is used with credential downloads. When I use "Limited" I see failures in QA tests, with "Absent" QA tests pass. 

My preference is to use "Limited" as this is easy to understand and means on upgrades we only need to increase the limits (no need to change "authentication.credential_download_certificate" from "Absent" to "Limited" when "Limited" is the default)

[~viglesias], [~rusvika] should we update QA tests and use "Limited" by default or stick with "Absent" on new installs?
The default value for the new property is "Absent", on upgraded system the value is "Limited" and the credential limits are set to 1,000,000 (i.e. unlimited)
[~sjones], I agree that "Limited" as a default makes more sense. It's easier to understand and it's more AWS compatible than "Absent"

[~viglesias], to make sure we're on the same page, are you voting for "Absent" or "Limited" as the default? 

[~sjones], would you mind also documenting how the credential_download_certificate and IAM limit properties relate to other ways of creating certificates (EUARE tools)? We need to make sure it's completely clear to admins what limits are enforced on which paths and how these properties work in combination. For example, my understanding is that if "Absent" is set, it still will be possible to generate more credentials using euare-usercreatecert depending on what limit is set for authentication.signing_certificates_limit. If that's the case, we need to spell it out.
[~rusvika], this fix disables limits for access keys and signing certificates however they are accessed.
I am fine with Limited 1,000,000 for upgrade and absent on new clouds.

Do we know why having "Limited" for new installs breaks the QA and is it hard to fix? Given that this fix disables IAM limits, having "Absent" results in non-AWS compatible behavior by default and also prevents proper credentials rotation (2 access keys/certs are needed for the rotation). I'm not convinced that "Absent" is acceptable as a default.

[~rusvika], credential download is a eucalyptus specific feature so is entirely non-AWS compatible. You cannot use credential download for credential rotation (credential download does not generate a new access key), so I'm not clear how a default of "Absent" would be an issue.

[~sjones], I guess I'm confused by your previous statement:

{quote}
this fix disables limits for access keys and signing certificates however they are accessed
{quote}

There are euare commands, like euare-usercreatecert and euare-useraddkey that allow creation (and immediate "download") of new certs/keys. EUCA-9940 introduced:
- authentication.access_keys_limit
- authentication.signing_certificates_limit

to control limits for these commands. However, based on the above quote, my understanding now is that these limits will be disabled by authentication.credential_download_certificate being set to "Absent", which means that a new cert will be generated by euare-usercreatecert only if none exists. The same for euare-useraddkey. Right? Then how can a user rotate credentials if only one credential at a time can be created. What am I missing?

The "authentication.credential_download_certificate" setting applies only to credential downloads, it does not impact the IAM API.

On upgraded systems all limits are set to 1,000,000 and "authentication.credential_download_certificate" is set to "Limited" so cloud behaviour is not changed on upgrade (4.1 behaviour with these setting is the same as 4.0 behaviour)

On new installs "authentication.credential_download_certificate" is set to "Absent" so there is no change from the pre-fix 4.1 behaviour.
